caption: Photographs show a damaged jet engine repaired with seatbelts during a refueling stop

candidates.title: Fan Belt
candidates.content:
Claim:
Photographs show a damaged jet engine repaired with seatbelts during a refueling stop.
Rating:
Miscaptioned
About this rating
The photographs displayed above have been circulated since at least as far back as 2001, in versions with text attributing them to Air China as well as a number of different airlines, in each case accompanied by the claim that a ground crew had hastily (and dangerously) repaired damaged jet engines on one of the airline's planes by using seat belts to hold them together, and the plane had taken off on a commercial flight in that state. While the pictures do show an engine that has been removed from an aircraft, when and where they were taken (and whether they have any connection to Air China or any other airline) is unknown. Nonetheless, they do not document a case of substandard repairs or an occurrence anything like the circumstances described in the accompanying text. The pictures included in the e-mail show engine fan blades that have suffered foreign object damage (FOD) such as encountering a bird strike or a hail storm, and the "seatbelts" are tie-down straps used to secure the engine to a shipping stand as it is removed from the aircraft for inspection, repair, or replacement.
candidates.description: Photographs show a damaged jet engine repaired with seatbelts during a refueling stop?

result.explanation: This assessment is evidence-based. The claim in the news caption is evaluated as false based on the evidence from Snopes.  The evidence shows that the image of a damaged jet engine secured with straps has been misrepresented. The straps are not seatbelts used for a hasty repair, but tie-down straps used during engine removal for inspection or repair.  The claim has circulated for years, falsely associating it with various airlines and implying dangerous, substandard repairs. The Snopes article debunks this claim.
supporting_evidence: Photographs show a damaged jet engine repaired with seatbelts during a refueling stop?

The photographs displayed above have been circulated since at least as far back as 2001, in versions with text attributing them to Air China as well as a number of different airlines, in each case accompanied by the claim that a ground crew had hastily (and dangerously) repaired damaged jet engines on one of the airline's planes by using seat belts to hold them together, and the plane had taken off on a commercial flight in that state.

While the pictures do show an engine that has been removed from an aircraft, when and where they were taken (and whether they have any connection to Air China or any other airline) is unknown. Nonetheless, they do not document a case of substandard repairs or an occurrence anything like the circumstances described in the accompanying text.

The pictures included in the e-mail show engine fan blades that have suffered foreign object damage (FOD) such as encountering a bird strike or a hail storm, and the "seatbelts" are tie-down straps used to secure the engine to a shipping stand as it is removed from the aircraft for inspection, repair, or replacement.

final_result.validation_summary: Internal check marked the caption as True, while external check from Snopes rated it as False with a high confidence score of 10, identifying the straps as tie-down straps, not seatbelts, used during engine removal for inspection or repair. The external evidence strongly refutes the claim in the original caption. There's a significant disagreement between internal and external checks. The external evidence is more reliable and detailed, focusing on the misrepresentation of the image circulating online. The claim is false and out of context, and the external evidence completely contradicts the claim made in the original caption. The image has been circulated for years, falsely attributing it to different airlines and implying unsafe repair methods; Snopes's fact check decisively clarifies the situation and provides credible evidence of the miscaptioned nature of the image. The original caption is entirely misleading and out of context. Therefore, the final verdict of the validation process supports the external evaluation, concluding that the original caption is out of context with high confidence.  The original caption is completely untrue and lacks factual basis. The straps are not seatbelts but are, instead, tie-down straps used for the transportation of the engine, not a quick repair during refueling. The external evidence convincingly addresses the factual inaccuracies of the news caption, which makes the caption completely out of context, with high confidence given to the findings of the external validation due to its depth of analysis and reliable evidence-based reasoning. The information provided strongly suggests that the claim is false and the image was misrepresented, rendering the original caption entirely out of context with a confidence of 10/10. Therefore, the claim is demonstrably and definitively untrue. The image shows damaged engine fan blades, most likely from foreign object damage such as a bird strike or hail, and the straps are tie-down straps for securing the engine during removal for inspection, repair or replacement, not seatbelts used in a hasty repair.
